text: I'm interested to hear if people think so too, want to give it a shot and let us know? (I think it's useful, and that there's also a lot of potential for it to be even more useful)

text: This sort of thing can be.  At scale the trick with this sort of thing is being able to filter out mundane/routine/well-behaved parts in order to focus on the "main" part of the evaluation.

elements.text: This sort of thing can be.  At scale the trick with this sort of thing is being able to filter out mundane/routine/well-behaved parts in order to focus on the "main" part of the evaluation.

text: I think you are dismissing the social/communal aspect too easily. Technology does not exist apart from society but with in it. I would go so far as to say as its impossible to solve technology problems without working on institutional/organisational problems.

elements.text: I think you are dismissing the social/communal aspect too easily. Technology does not exist apart from society but with in it. I would go so far as to say as its impossible to solve technology problems without working on institutional/organisational problems.

text: Dynamicland is like Papert's original LOGO experimental facility, which had the motorized turtle with the pen that could go up and down. It was fascinating in person, but the specialized equipment was not available to anyone else because he didn't productize it. Dynamicland when i visited, has cameras and projectors in the ceiling pointing down, a very unusual physical installation that is not going to be replicated much. It is basically a one-off research facility, and so what institutional or organizational problems is it solving? I don't see that as a relevant comment.
